reviewText: I loved watching this movie. True stories always are a win when the God Lord is in them.You have to watch this movie at least once in your life.
Title: Leonie

reviewText: wonderful true story of an American who falls in love with her employer, a great Japanese poet, has his child after he abandons her and returns to  Japan....... her son grows up to be a famous sculpture well known in the USA and Japan...even better because it's a true story.
Title: Leonie

reviewText: I've enjoyed Emily Mortimer in her other work, but she absolutely shines as Leonie Gilmour! Shid Nakamura is the lover and "husband" you'll love to hate and Jan Milligan is a pleasure to watch as the super-talented Isamu Noguchi, world-famous sculptor.The cinematography is brilliant and beautiful and the story never drags for a second. I can easily recommend "Leonie" to ages 12 and up!
summary: An incredible film filled with stellar performances!
Title: Leonie

reviewText: Leonie - The true story of Leonie Gilmour, set in the 1900's. Leonie is a educated American woman who agrees to become editor, and in time - lover, to the Japanese poet Yone Noguchi - I have to wonder how famous he would have been without her interjections. She bears his child (Isamu) and follows him to Japan only to find he already has a wife and sets her up as his mistress. She leaves him securing jobs teaching English. Once on her own she again gives birth and never reveals who the birth father is.It's also interesting because the film has a Japanese director, it's filmed in Japan and yet it seems truly to mock Japanese sexism. Yone is definitley the villian, sexist, violent and selfish, I believe she fell in love with him because of his creativity and his constant pursuit of her.Very good movie.
Title: Leonie

reviewText: Great true story of a young American girl, struggling to raise her children in Japan. My only problem was that it moved very slowly. I can do slow, but this one almost meandered. Just okay!
Title: Leonie

reviewText: 100 years later, one can easily forget how difficult it was for a women to forge her own path through the obstacles of every societal norm. Indeed Leonie Gilmore was not only ahead of her time, but even our time.Leonie Gilmore - an educated female at the turn of the century - was not an idealogue, as let's say Emma Goldman. She was not trying to convert anyone to a particular point of view but instead trying to live her life - totally independently of the social values or patriarchal constraints of both the American and the Japanese world.The two leads Emily Mortimer (as Leonie Gilmore) and Shidu Nakamura (as Yone Nagachi) are exceptional in their roles as two loves mismatched in their views.  He is a poet of Japanese birth who is still tied to the customs of his world and believes that women should walk behind the man and even consent to being a mere mistress of someone important.  She is a fiercely intelligent woman who walks behind nobody. However the child actors in the film are very weak characters, and I had to reduce my rating from 5 stars to 4 stars for that deficiency in the movie.  The color cinematography is glorious, with an Asian flair for color and texture.Like the Japanese tea ceremony, this film has many "moments" that made me reflect on important societal issues.  Leonie's mother is entirely self-sufficient in California on a farm, rooted to the earth, but fails to appreciate the importance of a father/male influence for her grandson. Leonie gets pregnant from another man, after moving to Japan, but refuses to tell her husband who the father is.  Leonie recognizes the artistic gifts of her son, and urges him to follow that path, even when he thinks that medical school is the better choice.  Leonie returns to the land at the end of her life...becoming unified in spirit and mind, with her own mother.If you can consider this film as poetry, rather like a sequence of Haiku poems, it will interest you.  If you expect fast dialogue or narrative movement, it will disappoint.  I don't expect a large American audience for this quietly interesting picture, but - notwithstanding its flaws - it made me think. Now that's something few Hollywood films do anymore.
summary: A Woman Who Makes Her Own Destiny
Title: Leonie

reviewText: Nurturing the artist... is nurturing the art. Noguchi's backstory is nearly invisible. And yet this extraordinary woman sets the fertile soil that will grow an artist.  There is a line that goes.. show me the student and I will see the teacher. This film shows usthe teacher who formed the artist, the teacher who steps out of the shadows to reveal what it is about love that evolves art.
summary: This woman! Filled empty spaces with love...
Title: Leonie

reviewText: Many times people wonder if the homosexuality or bisexuality of certain famous people will be covered in biopics of their lives.  This question was brought up in films about Amelia Earhart, Hoover, the guy in "A Beautiful Mind," and several others.  Please see the book "Queer Compulsions: Race, Nation, and Sexuality in the Affairs of Yon Noguchi."  In that book, the author writes that not only did Noguchi get with Leonie Gilmour, but he had a white wife, AND may have had a homoerotic relationship with a white dude named Charles Stoddard.  The author never asserts that the relationship may have been consummated; she just says their correspondence sure did get passionate.  Before watching this film, I wondered if they were going to sweep that relationship under the rug.  However, they do not.  We see Yon being very physical with a Western dude and Leonie expressing with exhaustion, "You've been missing several months and you come home unapologetic WITH A MAN!?"  In fact, I don't think the film ever shows Yon's Japanese wife, but here we see his possible male, white lover.  Wow!  On a side note, the reason why I know about Isamu Noguchi is because he was one of Frida Kahlo's many lovers.  However, that fact never comes up in the flick.
Title: Leonie

reviewText: Not sure what the other reviewers saw, but it was the portrait of a self absorbed person. Don't bore me?? Did she think the world was there for her amusement? Do we even know who the father of her daughter was? Or in this day and age, does it really matter? I especially like the part where she was teaching Japanese solders English during wartime. I wonder what they did with their new language? My guess was to kill American solders. I can think of many brave women who I would consider heroic, she sadly, is not one of them.
Title: Leonie

reviewText: No question this film shows the unusual life and parenting of a future great artist in Isamu Noguchi.  His mother gave him free reign to create everything from brush paintings to a small house by the sea.  He was a transcontinental kid led by his mother's free spirit. This is the story of her life, I hope all true, an American woman of an earlier century who stretched the bounds of convention by living with a Japanese man and living in Japan and within Japanese culture.  She likewise had another child, a daughter, in an unmarried and unconventional way.  She herself was a creative thinker and, from this film's portrayal, seemed to treasure all that is beautiful.  I recommend this insightful film and, especially, further exploration of the great artist that resulted from her singular vision.
summary: This gave great insight into Isamu Noguchi's Art
Title: Leonie

reviewText: It would be impossible to include every twist and turn of the lives of Leonie Gilmour and Yone Noguchi so the makers of this film chose to focus on Leonie and they made the correct choice.  She was a woman very much ahead of her time -- a student at the very young Bryn Mawr College, intelligent, aggressive, not afraid to embrace life regardless of what it brought her way.  Emily Mortimer is a very convincing Leonie -- she captures the spirit of a very definitely spirited woman.  The supporting actors are all fine in their roles too.  The film was obviously made on a tight budget but that constraint doesn't harm the picture -- it contributes to making it the intimate film that it is.  Yone Noguchi -- the father of Leonie's son, the sculptor, artist, set designer, etc. Isamu Noguchi -- was a complex man -- a poet from Japan who gained fame in the US with the help of Leonie who edited his work.  A man who was engaged to one woman, impregnated another, while also having relationships with male acquaintances and who ultimately fathered nine children with the Japanese woman that he married.  Isamu Noguchi like his mother also was a free-spirited who traveled the world in pursuit of his art.  Ultimately this is the story of three very gifted people -- a mother, father and son who lived an unconventional life -- at times together, but mostly apart -- and yet all achieved what can only be called remarkable lives.  The final scenes of the film are quite touching and beautiful in keeping with the spirit of the people involved who pursued art and beauty in their daily lives.I defy anyone to see the film and not come away wanting to know more about all three of these people.
summary: Well told story of the life of an independent woman
Title: Leonie

reviewText: 3 1/2 starsDirector Hisako Matsui films this movie mostly in English, but in a very Japanese style that many Westerners will find difficult to interpret or enjoy. (explained below)This movie uses the life of Leonie Gilmour and her son Isamu Noguchi, the famous sculptor, as a backdrop to convey social issues including women's rights during the early 1900's.  It is poetic in both dialog and cinematography at moments.  However, it may be a little dry for many viewers.THE PLOT: Leonie is a bright, educated, American woman who agrees to become editor, and ultimately lover, to the Japanese poet Yone Noguchi.  She bears his child (Isamu) out of wedlock and follows him to Japan.  One can imagine the resulting complications for a smart woman of pre-suffrage United States.  The recounting of Leonie's time in Japan serves to amplify those professional, social and romantic conflicts as she deals with the cultural shock of life for women in Japan (an even more patriarchal society).  Leonie comes to the realization that she will only be his mistress as Yone already has a wife.  He tells her "this is the culture of Japan and there is nothing you can do about it".  To her credit, Leonie takes her son and forges her own path while encouraging his strengths, spending years more in Japan.  This movie expounds on that line of finding one's true self as Isamu grows to college age.  He secures a benefactor and applies himself to becoming a doctor in America to show gratitude (despite the fact he is clearly an artist by nature).  When Leonie finds out Isamu's course of study as a doctor, she attempts to set him straight.The backdrop of post industrialized Japan is also very interesting.  The references are fleeting, but the movie opens near the start of the Russo-Japanese War.  Japan had recently emerged from essentially a feudal period, after observing the changing nature of warfare during the American Civil War.  In just a few decades, Japan emerged and then defeated the largest military power of their time (Russia), much to the world's surprise.  The movie shows early on how Anti-Japanese sentiment in the US had already intensified before WWI.For those not familiar with Japanese literature and film, there is not that western focus of climax and Dénouement that we are used to.  I admit, Japanese lit classes were my least favorite.  Their stories tend to amble along and then simply end.  The journey or process is more important than the destination.  As Leonie's Tea Ceremony instructor more aptly puts it "...the expression is MOST important.  The tension of drama lies in the delicate grace of a perfect moment, the fragility of something beautiful." This style is fine when illustrating a life story since that is kind of like life.  We muddle through it, and then someday it just ends.  This movie is not so much an entertainment piece as it is an illustration, an expression.  Western viewers will find the character development lacking as the story skips from event to event.  Remember, this isn't as much a biography as they would have one believe.Special mention should go to Emily Mortimer who proves she is far more than just a favorite actress from the UK.  Her performance here is truly outstanding. I dropped my rating to 3 1/2 stars only because I felt some of the issues they tried to express were not that effective and the movie will be tedious to many viewers.  However, the production values are excelent and the movie is beautiful in many places.
summary: DON'T BORE HER BY BEING ORDINARY!  Filmed in English, but very Japanese style
Title: Leonie

reviewText: The best part of this movie is the look at the Japanese culture. Some see courage in Leonie's fervent search for independence; I just see her making a lot of bad decisions.
Title: Leonie

reviewText: Nothing at all like Merchant Ivory productions. Emily Mortimer was awful and much of the rest of the acting stiff. Very disappointing.
Title: Leonie

reviewText: The movie was nice. I especially enjoyed watching the lovely Emily Mortimer. A very good director. Great lighting and backdrops.
summary: A nice movie to view when you have some relaxing time
